channel.title: BBC News - Home

item.title: Prince Andrew served with papers, accuser's team claims
item.description: Legal documents were served to a police officer in Windsor last month, US court papers say.

item.title: 9/11 anniversary: Terrorism failed to undermine our freedom, says PM
item.description: Boris Johnson says that while the terror threat remains, people refuse "to live in permanent fear".

item.title: MI5: 31 late-stage terror plots foiled in four years in UK
item.description: The terror threat to the UK remains "a real and enduring thing", the head of the security service says.

item.title: M1: Arrest warrant for mum accused of killing kids in crash
item.description: Mary McCann misses a court date where she was due to answer charges following a crash on the M1.

item.title: Tax on landlords could pay for social care, says Keir Starmer
item.description: The Labour leader responds to the PM's plan to raise taxes to pay for the NHS and social care.

item.title: Raducanu: 'Isn't it every 18-year-old's dream?'
item.description: Britain's "cool, calm and composed" US Open finalist Emma Raducanu is meeting the challenges of her first overseas Grand Slam head on.

item.title: Afghanistan: UN condemns Taliban's brutal crackdown on protests
item.description: The United Nations says the Taliban used live ammunition, batons and whips on protesters, killing four.

item.title: Two of six Palestinian prison escapees recaptured - Israel
item.description: A manhunt was launched after six inmates tunnelled out of a prison in northern Israel on Monday.

item.title: Driver shortage: 50,000 more HGV driving tests promised a year
item.description: The government will make it quicker to get an HGV driver licence, amid an industry-wide shortage.

item.title: Agnès Buzyn: France ex-health minister under investigation
item.description: Former health minister Agnès Buzyn is investigated for "endangering lives" after leaving her role.

item.title: All of Disney's 2021 movies to debut exclusively in cinemas
item.description: All films set to come out 2021 will be released in cinemas, handing a boost to struggling venues.

item.title: Why Don't We: US boy band accuse manager of mental and financial abuse
item.description: US group Why Don't We claim they were made "hostages in our own home" and had their food restricted.

item.title: COP26: Poorest countries fear not reaching UK for climate summit
item.description: Twenty of the world's poorest countries face hotel quarantine before the event in Glasgow.

item.title: The Papers: 'Andrew served' in abuse case and PM Covid warning
item.description: The papers cover a court case against the Duke of York and the risk of tighter virus restrictions.

item.title: Afghanistan: BBC catches up with Afghan journalist who fled Kabul
item.description: Wahida Faizi spoke to a reporter in August saying she feared the Taliban would kill her for her work.

item.title: Ros Atkins on... lorry driver shortages
item.description: Ros Atkins looks at why there's a lack of drivers and how it's affecting UK businesses.

item.title: Covid: The Chelmsford bench telling women's stories of the pandemic
item.description: Pippa Bloom, who had to shield due to Covid, says sharing her experience was "almost therapeutic".

item.title: Powerchair football: 'My hat-trick got Northern Ireland to the World Cup'
item.description: Patrick Cumiskey was diagnosed with Duchenne muscular dystrophy when he was eight months old.

item.title: Week in pictures: 4-10 September 2021
item.description: A selection of powerful images from all over the globe, taken this week.

item.title: Quiz of the week: What did the 'talking' duck say?
item.description: How closely have you been paying attention to what's been going on during the past seven days?

item.title: 'Vaccine passports make me even more reluctant to get a Covid jab'
item.description: The new uni term starts soon but anyone who isn't fully vaccinated won't be allowed into clubs.

item.title: Covid: UK expats struggle with Australia lockdowns
item.description: People who left the UK to settle in Australia tell what life has been like during six lockdowns.

item.title: Manic Street Preachers: 'A Design For Life saved us'
item.description: The Welsh band on Trojan horse tracks, losing Richey Edwards and finding a new piano-pop direction.

item.title: Why is the UK waiting when others are jabbing young teens?
item.description: Concerns over a very rare heart side-effect are giving vaccine experts pause for thought.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid: President Biden's comments on vaccines fact-checked
item.description: The US president said he was "frustrated" with the nearly 80 million Americans still not vaccinated

item.title: MH17: One father's testimony marked by despair and a rucksack
item.description: Relatives reveal the pain of securing justice for those who died when the flight was brought down.

item.title: London's Oyster card: Are its days numbered?
item.description: Passengers prefer paying by contactless which means Oyster card usage is dwindling. What next?

item.title: 'The near-death experience that made me a top musician'
item.description: When Tony Kofi had a near-fatal accident, he had a vision of himself playing a musical instrument. It would change his life forever.

item.title: Who rescues migrants in the Channel?
item.description: The number of migrants crossing the English Channel is increasing, but who is responsible for them?

item.title: 11 September 2001: The conspiracy theories still spreading after 20 years
item.description: Conspiracy theories about 9/11 continue to gain traction online, two decades after the attacks.

item.title: Crazy love: Behind China's crackdown on K-pop and other fan clubs
item.description: Chinese authorities have made it clear that they are not tolerant of overzealous celebrity fans.

item.title: Elizabeth Holmes: Has the Theranos scandal changed Silicon Valley?
item.description: Could a Theranos scandal happen again or has Silicon Valley learnt its lesson?

item.title: 'I'll be at front of queue to change my slave name'
item.description: Descendants of African slaves welcome a Dutch city's decision to scrap fees for changing names.

item.title: Can Raducanu end 44-year drought? Briton and fellow teenager Fernandez set for US Open final
item.description: Emma Raducanu seeks to become the first British woman to win a Grand Slam singles title in 44 years when she takes on fellow teenager Leylah Fernandez in the US Open final.

item.title: 'He has that something extra' - Old Trafford awaits Ronaldo return
item.description: After a "mind-boggling" debut 18 years ago, BBC Sport looks ahead to Cristiano Ronaldo's Manchester United return.

item.title: Bottas heads 'sprint' race qualifying from team-mate Hamilton
item.description: Mercedes' Valtteri Bottas beats team-mate Lewis Hamilton to qualify fastest for Saturday's Italian Grand Prix 'sprint' race.

item.title: Postponed Test earmarked for summer 2022 as ECB denies IPL affected call-off
item.description: The postponed England-India Test could take place in the summer of 2022, says England and Wales Cricket Board chief Tom Harrison.

item.title: South American Premier League players set to avoid bans and be available for clubs
item.description: Premier League players are set to be cleared to compete this weekend after Brazil reportedly dropped their complaint about their failure to report for international duty.

item.title: Football Focus: 'I watch games thinking we're going to lose' - Fans discuss Mikel Arteta's Arsenal
item.description: Arsenal fans discuss the club's poor start to the season which sees the sit club at the bottom of the Premier League after three consecutive defeats.

item.title: Afghanistan: What has changed in 20 years
item.description: Women's education and independent media have been the success stories, but all this might change now.

item.title: Afghanistan: A new order begins under the Taliban's governance
item.description: The Taliban's new ministers have taken office - but are they any different this time around?

item.title: Afghan robotics team: Inspirational women begin new chapter
item.description: The BBC speaks to the women's robotics team about their ordeal trying to leave Afghanistan.

item.title: Afghanistan crisis: Five lessons learned (or not) since 9/11
item.description: Some fatal mistakes have undermined the fight against terror, says the BBC's Frank Gardner.

item.title: Chaos and confusion: The frenzied final hours of the Afghan government
item.description: Through interviews with insiders, BBC News has pieced together an account of how Afghanistan’s government unravelled.

item.title: Afghanistan: Could Pakistani drones hit the Panjshir Valley?
item.description: There are claims that Pakistan has used drones against anti-Taliban forces in Afghanistan.

item.title: Afghanistan: The pledge binding al-Qaeda to the Taliban
item.description: The history of the complex relationship between the two groups.

item.title: Afghanistan: Who's who in the Taliban leadership
item.description: What we know about the top figures in the militant group that has taken control of Afghanistan.

item.title: The Taliban embrace social media: 'We too want to change perceptions'
item.description: Famed for their shunning of technology, the Taliban are realising they need to be on social media too.

item.title: Afghanistan: What's life like since the Taliban took over?
item.description: People around the country tell the BBC they have lost basic freedoms and are struggling to survive.

item.title: Flu jab 2021: Who’s eligible for a free vaccine?
item.description: This year's roll out has expanded in an attempt to shield against a double whammy of flu and Covid.

item.title: Covid: How do I get the vaccine and will I need a booster?
item.description: A third dose is being offered to up to half a million people in the UK with weakened immune systems.

item.title: Covid passports: How do I get one and when will I need it?
item.description: People in Scotland will need to be fully vaccinated to go to clubs, sporting events and concerts.

item.title: Long Covid: What is it and what are the symptoms?
item.description: Significant numbers have had long-term problems after recovering from the original infection.

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The progress made in vaccinating the country's population, as more than 48 million people have received at least one dose.

item.title: What are the travel rules for Spain, Portugal, Malta and other holiday hotspots?
item.description: What you need to know about going to Portugal, Spain, Greece, France, Malta, Italy and Turkey.

item.title: Back to school: How are pupils being kept Covid-safe?
item.description: Many children are returning to school after the holidays, while Scottish pupils already returned.

item.title: Covid: Will I need a jab and what will university be like this term?
item.description: Many Covid restrictions have been lifted for students going to university this term.

item.title: Covid rules: What's changing in Wales, Scotland, England and Northern Ireland?
item.description: Lockdown rules are changing across the UK, but some restrictions remain in place.

item.title: Universal credit: When will the £20 increase stop?
item.description: The government has confirmed the £20 boost will end in the autumn.

item.title: What are the rules and guidance for face masks and coverings?
item.description: Masks are no longer compulsory in England, but remain necessary in other parts of the UK.

item.title: Covid: Which children are being vaccinated and why?
item.description: Millions of children, including 16- to 17-year-olds, are now being offered a Covid vaccine.

item.title: What are the holiday rules for travel to green, amber and red list countries?
item.description: A traffic light system is in place setting out rules for entering the UK

item.title: Covid: How is furlough changing and when will it end?
item.description: The furlough scheme, which protected millions of jobs during the pandemic, is in its final weeks.

item.title: The hard men removing squatters in Spain
item.description: Some squatters in Spain demand cash before leaving - so eviction firms have arisen to handle the talks.

item.title: Afghanistan: Shukria Barakzai's whispered voice notes and dramatic escape
item.description: The desperate messages sent by Afghan politician Shukria Barakzai to a UK MP as the Taliban tried to hunt her down.

item.title: Afghanistan: The 'undefeated' Panjshir Valley - an hour from Kabul
item.description: The Panjshir Valley has been a flashpoint in Afghanistan's turbulent history - now it's happening again.

item.title: Bilal Sarwary: 'The plane hit the tower and all our lives changed'
item.description: Afghan journalist Bilal Sarwary was selling carpets when 9/11 happened. From that day on, everything changed.

item.title: Shot in the head in Angola, left for dead, now a Wetherspoons star
item.description: Cesar Kimbirima fled Angola after being shot four times and spending five months in a coma.
